awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Adapting the Fluid Projection Method to Model Elasto-plastic Materials
awd_abstract_narration:
There are two main ways that materials deform under an applied force. The deformation can be elastic, so that when the force is removed the material recovers its original shape. Alternatively, the deformation can be plastic, whereby the material undergoes irreversible changes that may subsequently lead to breakage. Many materials of technological importance exhibit a combination of these two types of deformation depending on the applied force, and are called elasto-plastic. One example are bulk metallic glasses (BMGs), which are alloys that have an amorphous atomic arrangement in contrast to most metals. BMGs have desirable properties, such as the ability to be processed like plastics, making them attractive candidates for many applications (e.g. next-generation smartphone cases) due to considerable improvements in manufacturing efficiency. However, experimental measurements of BMG breakage properties show wide variations, limiting their usage. To overcome these limitations, it is essential to develop predictive theoretical and computational models of BMG elasto-plasticity. This project is based on a surprising similarity between the equations for elasto-plastic materials and the equations for incompressible fluids. Using this similarity, computational approaches that were originally developed for fluid flow will be translated to elasto-plasticity. These computational methods will be used in collaboration with theorists and experimentalists to study the fracture properties of BMGs. The ultimate aim is to provide a practical engineering tool for predicting when elasto-plastic materials will break, and how to best design structures using them. This work will be undertaken as part of an integrated program of research, teaching, and mentorship, and will involve outreach activities in New England, including a local library lecture series.

The projection method of Chorin (1968) is a well-established approach for simulating the incompressible Navier-Stokes equations for fluid flow. This proposal is based on a surprising mathematical correspondence between fluids in the incompressible limit and elasto-plastic solids in the quasi-static limit (when inertia can be neglected). In this proposal, this correspondence is harnessed to translate several modern numerical approaches derived from Chorin's projection method to quasi-static elasto-plasticity, resulting in a practical and powerful set of new simulation tools for a different class of physical problem. Compared to existing techniques, the resultant numerical methods are likely to be especially well-suited to problems involving large plastic deformations. An example type of elasto-plastic material are the bulk metallic glasses (BMGs), which are alloys with many favorable properties such as excellent strength and wear resistance. The numerical methods developed here will be used in a collaboration with theorists and experimentalists to study the fracture toughness properties of BMGs, with the aim of predicting BMG toughness over a wide range of experimental conditions. The PI plans to expand the graduate curriculum in numerical methods to address a pressing need in this area. Open source software will be released as part of this project, and the PI will train students in best practices to make software accessible to a broad audience.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Bulk metallic glasses (BMGs) are a new type of metallic alloy whose atoms have a random, amorphous arrangement in contrast to most metals. BMGs have many favorable properties, such as high strength and wear resistance, and the ability to be processed at lower temperatures, with less energy. Despite these advantages, BMGs can fail and break in complicated ways that are poorly understood. Because of this it is essential to develop ways to accurately model and simulate them.

BMGs can be modeled as an elastoplastic material: when subjected to small loads they deform elastically, whereas at large loads they undergo irreversible, plastic deformation. This project was based on a surprising observation that the equations for an elastoplastic BMG have a mathematical connection to the equations for fluid flow. Even though these two systems–BMGs and fluids—are completely different, this connection allows simulation methods to be translated between them. In particular, the project showed that the well-known Chorin projection method for fluid flow can be adapted to create a powerful and efficient way to simulate BMGs.

Using this idea, the project resulted in a new method for three-dimensional simulation of BMGs suitable for running on large supercomputers. This method was used to probe and understand BMG failure properties. In the fluid flow literature, methods have been proposed that result in very high solution accuracy. These were also converted to create several highly-accurate BMG solution methods. The methods generalize beyond BMGs to any elastoplastic material, and several associated scientific software libraries were released.

The project also showed that the simulation methods for fluid flow can adapted to a third system, of poroelastic materials, such as sponges and biological gels. A projection method for poroelastic materials was developed and it was used to explore the mechanical properties of these materials.

The research project provided opportunities for the training of graduate students, and partially supported five Ph.D. students who were trained in scientific computing, mathematical modeling, and data analysis. The work was also accompanied by a series of talks at libraries in New England on popular science topics, such as the calculation of pi, and the mathematics of fractals. Furthermore, the project resulted in the development of a series of YouTube videos on graduate-level scientific computing.
